Hi all.

I would just like to know how others handle certain junit testing=

situations. I'm new to unit testing so please bear with me. I have a
metho=
d that contains a lot of try and catch statements:

try{
	statement1
	state=
ment2
}
catch(ExceptionType1 e1){
	System.err.println("The following except=
ion occurred " +
e1.toString());
}

I know that this is not a very good way=
 of handling exceptions but I'm
struggling to find a better way. Another al=
ternative is to use a logger
such as log4j, but this does not help much. Th=
e problem is how do I test
if the method is not working properly, as the ex=
ception was caught and
won't be visible to JUnit.

The most obvious solutio=
n would be to let the method throw all
exceptions that are generated. The p=
roblem is that there are 5 or 6
different types of exceptions that this met=
hod can generate and this
seems to make my code very messy.

Could anyone p=
lease tell me what is the proper approach to this, or
refer me to any relev=
ant reading.

Thanks in advance.
Pico
